instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message:
I Have:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>

I don't have:
5V Rails
Mouse Light

Logic Board looks good, don't have any water damage or something like that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message:
You will not get a mouse light because it does not turn on. If it is not turning on, it cannot power a USB device. The purpose of plugging in a mouse is to see if the machine can POST, which can only happen once it has turned on. 

Do you have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message:
[USER="1"]larossmann[/USER], Thank you for the answer.
I don't get both: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present? If it is present, is it 3.3v, 0v, or jumping up and down between 0v and 3.3v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message: I have 3.3v on <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message: Well this is pointing to bad <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> tells <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> to turn on. If <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is not shorted to ground[I](which indicates no problem after <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>)[/I] and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present[I](indicating no problem before <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>)[/I] then I imagine your problem is <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Is there a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>? If there is no short to ground on these lines something is going on in <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area. Inspect it closely before replacing the chip to see if there are hints of anything else being the problem, and if there are none, just replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message: U mean: <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b - no pp5v
threads.message: Sure, go ahead and replace <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.....
